Chapter on the Perfection of Patience, Part 12 of the Bodhisattva Canon, Chapter 8 on the Perfection of Patience
At that time the Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
What is called the perfection of patience of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
For the sake of supreme perfect enlightenment, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas diligently study and practice this Dharma and practice the bodhisattva path.
ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, by abiding in this perfection of forbearance, are fully endowed with the power of forbearance and establish a firm and upright nature. They are able to endure the cold, heat, hunger, thirst, snakes, scorpions, mosquitoes, gadflies, wind, and sun, and other such contacts. They are also able to endure coarse and evil speech, vulgar words and phrases, and the intense suffering arising from the body, such as the sharp and severe pain that takes away one's life up to death. They are able to endure all such suffering.
ÅšÄriputra!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to possess this, it is called the perfection of forbearance.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
In my long night of not yet attaining Buddhahood in the past, while practicing the conduct of a bodhisattva, I always cultivated forbearance.
ÅšÄriputra addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How did the World-Honored One, when a bodhisattva, cultivate forbearance and practice the conduct of a bodhisattva?
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:

I remember in the past, when I was practicing bodhisattva conduct, many beings came and insulted me, scolded me, and reproached me with improper words, speaking all kinds of improper and vile words in my presence.
ÅšÄriputra!
At that time, because I was practicing the perfection of forbearance, I controlled my mind and did not give rise to anger, stinginess, or distress, but only thought like this:
'Among all conditioned things, there is no dharma that is easier to obtain than insults and reproaches. Therefore, I should now cultivate equanimity.
Moreover, I should give rise to kindness and compassion towards them.
Why is this?

Because in the world, many beings mostly dwell in insulting and reproaching, and due to this karma, they will again experience such a retribution of being insulted and reproached. In all their lives, they will always obtain an ugly and repulsive body.
I now do not enjoy ugly things, so how could I enjoy practicing insulting and reproaching?
Why is this?
Thus, reviling evil deeds is called inappropriate action, unreasonable action, the action of a fool, inferior action, the action of an unwholesome person, and the action of a non-sage.
Because of this action, one falls into the hells, the animal realm, and the realm of the king of the dead.

Moreover, because of this action, one becomes an associate of the evil destinies. Because of this action, one experiences the body of a poor yaká¹£a, and because of this action, one experiences the fundamental retribution of a poor yaká¹£a. Because of this action, one experiences the body of a poor hungry ghost, and because of this action, one experiences the fundamental retribution of a poor hungry ghost. Because of this action, one experiences the body of a poor human, and because of this action, one experiences the fundamental retribution of a poor human. Moreover, because of this reviling action, one experiences the inferior destinies and the fundamental retribution of the inferior destinies.
I should not now seek an inferior destiny.
Why is it so?
If I seek to do such things, what difference is there between me and other sentient beings?
However, those sentient beings do not accord with principle, and since I accord with principle, I should not be the same as them.'
ÅšÄriputra!
These bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who practice the perfection of forbearance should follow me in cultivating and learning this Dharma.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
When these bodhisattvas are reviled, scolded, and blamed by others, they are able to contemplate and endure it with the correct Dharma in mind.
Because these bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have attained such forbearance and power, they will also attain immeasurable wonderful roots of goodness.
Even if one were to fill a world with precious treasures and give it away, it would not compare to the previous merit.
Why is it so?
Because this practice of forbearance is something that only an extremely good person is able to cultivate.
Why is it so?
All sentient beings are often bound by slander, abuse, and reproach, and for this reason they transmigrate in birth and death and cannot cut off the cycle.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
These bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who practice the perfection of forbearance should encourage themselves and carefully contemplate, thinking like this:
'If I am scolded and reviled by others, can I still contemplate the Buddha's enlightenment, the Dharma, and the Saá¹…gha?'
If one can contemplate, then it is good. If one cannot contemplate, it is not good.
One should further contemplate the Buddha, contemplate enlightenment, and contemplate the Dharma and the Saá¹…gha with immeasurable other skillful means.'
ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having contemplated in this way, should observe, 'What differences and distinctions do I have now with all sentient beings?'
Why is it so?
Those sentient beings who now give rise to anger and harm towards my body have never contemplated the Buddha's enlightenment, the Dharma, or the Saá¹…gha.
If I were to be the same as them and not contemplate, what difference and what special and wondrous characteristics would there be between me and sentient beings?
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva further contemplates:
'If one's mind gives rise to abandonment when others are presently angry, and one has never contemplated the Buddha's enlightenment, the Dharma, or the Saá¹…gha, this is not appropriate for me.'
He further thinks like this:
'If I give rise to anger towards them, then I will be without wisdom and without the power of patience, and I will also abandon my original vow.
Why is this?
If one gives rise to anger, then one will not have this thought:
I should embrace all sentient beings, I should not abandon all sentient beings.
If I give rise to anger towards a single sentient being, I cannot be called a bodhisattva who embraces and guides.
Who has requested me to practice the bodhisattva path?
Moreover, in the past I made this vow:
I will quickly realize supreme, perfect enlightenment and extensively proclaim the true Dharma for the sake of sentient beings.
As soon as I made this vast vow, the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, all certified me. I thought like this:
This son of good family, having aroused his mind and abided in such supreme perfect enlightenment, will extensively proclaim the true Dharma for the sake of sentient beings.
Moreover, at present, the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, with unobstructed cognition and unobstructed vision, directly realize and know me.
Therefore, when others slander, scold, and rebuke me, if I give rise to anger, or if I abandon the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹…gha, I should not recall [those offenses].
Why is it so?

In the present eastern direction, in buddha-realms as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, there are tathÄgatas, arhats, perfectly enlightened ones as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River who presently uphold [the Dharma].
That Buddha-World-Honored One also knows my mind and the correct vows I give rise to.
In the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above and below, it is the same.
When I give rise to these correct vows, the Buddhas praise my power of forbearance with the same voice. Therefore, I should not roar like a lion and then make the sound of a jackal.
Roaring like a lion means I will realize the great power of forbearance;
Making the sound of a jackal means to be angry and scold others towards sentient beings.
ÅšÄriputra!
This Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva further thinks like this:

'If sentient beings in the world benefit themselves before benefiting others, I am also like this. If I benefit sentient beings before benefiting them, what difference is there between me and the world?
What special and rare characteristics are there?'
He further thinks like this:
'If sentient beings in the world do what is unbeneficial to each other, then this does what is unbeneficial to that.
I am also like this. Sentient beings do harm to me, and I also do harm to them.
If this is the case, what is the difference between me and sentient beings?
ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should cultivate and study in this Dharma.
He also thinks like this:
Sentient beings in the world are mutually hostile. If they obtain benefits from each other, they consider each other friends. If they do not obtain benefits, they kill each other.
I see such deep faults, so I should not observe that all sentient beings do beneficial and pleasant things for my body, and do harmful things to my body.
But he only thinks like this:
I will now definitely benefit all sentient beings, in order to fulfill the perfection of forbearance.
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Even if they do no good for me, for many hundreds of koá¹­is of eons,
Seeing those sentient beings undergoing various sufferings, I will never remain in a mind of equanimity.
If they mutually obtain worldly wealth and benefits, they praise each other and become good friends,
But if they mutually do not obtain worldly wealth and benefits, they become enemies and harm each other.
Even if this JambudvÄ«pa, or even the world systems of a trichiliocosm,
Were filled with precious treasures and offered to me, they would always seek me as a wise and good friend.
Even if they were to come with sharp swords and cut off all the limbs of my body,
I would have a mind of equal benefit and no duality towards those sentient beings.
I will endure all the difficulties and sufferings, including being reviled by others,
And will praise the power of forbearance for sentient beings, and also abide myself in great forbearance.
The violent and evil beings in the world, using knives, poison, and other means to harm each other,
Are able to reconcile them and make them good friends, this is the characteristic of the wise and holy.
I should not learn from the foolish people of the world, and should also be different from them,
Because the practices of ordinary beings and sages differ, in terms of samsara and nirvana.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of forbearance, they should cultivate and study the true Dharma in this way.
ÅšÄriputra!
These bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should further think like this:

Even if they were to undergo harm from beings for hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of great kalpas, using various means such as knives, sticks, tiles, stones, and clods of earth, as long as they could barely maintain their lives for a short while, they should still rejoice and think like this:
How wonderful! Such beings, these holy ones, do not completely destroy my life.
From then on, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva will further increase his practice and have this thought:
Even if beings were to cut off my head for as many eons as there are sands in the Ganges River in the time it takes to take seven steps, I would never give rise to anger or hatred towards them.
Why is this?

Anger quickly destroys the wholesome roots accumulated over a hundred thousand great eons. If my wholesome roots are destroyed by anger, I will have to diligently practice the holy path for a hundred thousand great eons again.
If it were like this, anuttara-samyak-sambodhi would be extremely difficult to attain. Therefore, I should don the armor of patience and use firm strength to destroy the army of anger.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

For a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who abides in the Great Vehicle, if angry thoughts arise, MÄra will find an opportunity. Having found an opportunity, he will be able to create obstacles to anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
ÅšÄriputra!
An angry mind can disturb the path to enlightenment, and a disturbed mind can give rise to the evil mÄras' demonic activities.

ÅšÄriputra!
These kinds of angry thoughts can disturb one's enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva whose mind is disturbed, who is employed by the evil mÄras to create the works of mÄras.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of forbearance, they think like this:
'For a long time, all sentient beings have been sought after by the evil mÄras who look for opportunities, namely anger.'
ÅšÄriputra!
I will now explain this matter in detail for you.

I remember in the past, when I was a great sage named Practice Site, there was an evil demon who transformed into five hundred strong and abusive men who always followed me, uttering all sorts of evil words. Whether walking, coming and going, standing, sitting, lying down, in the monastery, quiet room, village, or lay household, whether in the streets or in secluded places, wherever I sat or stood, these transformed demons used coarse and evil words to revile and scold me, for a full five hundred years without ever stopping.
ÅšÄriputra!

I remember that for five hundred years I was scolded and reviled by the demons, but I never gave rise to the slightest resentment towards them, always giving rise to compassion and rescue, and observing them with this attitude.
ÅšÄriputra!
At that time, I had this thought:

'If there are good men who guard the precepts and possess many good dharmas, and whose greed, hatred, and delusion are by nature light and few, not only do they bring about benefit for them, but they also say that I am one who practices what is difficult to practice.'
Moreover, it is not only by benefiting them that one can attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
Why is this?

If there are sentient beings who are obstinate and difficult to subdue, who violate the precepts and possess all kinds of evil dharmas, who are by nature turbid and heavy with greed, hatred, and delusion, if I were to benefit them, then it would be said that I am a practitioner of difficulties.
Because by benefiting them, I will quickly attain supreme perfect enlightenment, in order to first enable them to realize quiescence.'
ÅšÄriputra!
When these bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have a mind of anger and resentment present before them, they should give rise to such great correct mindfulness.
If they give rise to this mindfulness, all beneficial matters will be quickly fulfilled.
ÅšÄriputra!
The TathÄgata, in the past, due to practicing such a bodhisattva practice of the perfection of forbearance, attained supreme perfect enlightenment.

Therefore, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who wish to seek unsurpassed perfect enlightenment should always fully accomplish the power of patience, and be able to endure all the cold, heat, hunger, thirst, wind, sun, mosquitoes, gadflies, snakes, scorpions, and other contacts, and also be able to endure coarse and evil speech, vulgar words and phrases, and the intense suffering arising from the body, the severe pain that takes away one's life up to death. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abiding in this patience, quickly being able to accomplish the perfection of patience.

What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' perfection of patience?

The bodhisattvas' patience is to be without anger, this is the bodhisattvas' patience; to be without resentment, this is the bodhisattvas' patience;

In brief, it should be known that all the TathÄgata's powers, fearlessnesses, unique qualities of a Buddha, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, immeasurable perfect Buddha-dharmas, are all accomplished by the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's perfection of patience.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of patience, they should fully possess the correct practices of patience.
ÅšÄriputra!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are scolded, they will never retaliate, because they skillfully understand that words are like echoes.
If they are beaten, they will never retaliate, because they skillfully understand that the physical form is like a reflected image.
If they are angered, they will never retaliate, because they skillfully observe that the mind is like an illusion and a phantom.
Whether praised or reviled, they are ultimately free from love and hatred, because they skillfully understand that their own virtues are perfect and complete.

They do not seek praise and avoid blame, because they are able to skillfully observe and have vast wisdom.
They are not brought down by slander or elevated by praise, because their virtues are well-established and unshakable.
They have never been averse to suffering, because they deeply cherish those sentient beings who suffer.
They have never delighted in pleasant things, because they know that conditioned happiness is impermanent by nature.
The eight worldly dharmas cannot taint them, because they do not rely on any form of existence.
They are well able to endure their own suffering, because they never cause others to suffer.
They never lose heart in the supreme enlightenment, because the provisions for awakening are well-perfected.
They are well able to endure having their limbs cut off, even to the point of having their heads cut off, because they aspire to the adamantine body of a TathÄgata.
They are able to endure the cutting and slicing of their flesh, in order to seek the TathÄgata's sublime physical marks.

These kinds of characteristics are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's perfection of forbearance.
One should study in this way.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

The characteristics of forbearance for bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practicing the perfection of forbearance are as follows: The forbearance practiced by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas is called ultimate forbearance.
Why is it so?
If one thinks, I am able to forbear insults and abuse and give rise to forbearance, this is called innate forbearance. Such forbearance is not ultimate forbearance.
If one thinks, Who is able to insult and who is being insulted? and gives rise to forbearance, this is called the forbearance of contemplating phenomena.
If one thinks that the eye can scold the eye, and gives rise to patience, this is called the patience of contemplating the various sense bases.

If one thinks that in this there is neither one who can scold nor one who is scolded, and gives rise to patience, this is called the patience of realizing that all dharmas are devoid of sentient beings.
ÅšÄriputra!
Such patiences are not the ultimate patience of a bodhisattva.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
If one thinks that the sounds of scolding are just various letters, this is called the patience of echo sounds, and such patience is not ultimate patience.
If one thinks that both oneself and the other are impermanent, this is called the patience of realizing impermanence.
If one thinks that the other has delusion while oneself is without delusion, this is called the patience of superiority and inferiority.
If one thinks that the other is not right while oneself is right, this is called the patience of correspondence and non-correspondence.

If one thinks that the other abides in the wrong path while oneself abides in the right path, this is called the patience of the separation of the two paths, and such patience is not ultimate patience.

If one says, 'I can endure emptiness but not the views,' 'I can endure signlessness but not the various perceptions,' 'I can endure wishlessness but not the various aspirations,' 'I can endure non-action but not the various activities,' 'I can endure the exhaustion of afflictions but not the afflictions,' 'I can endure the various wholesome [dharmas] but not the unwholesome,' 'I can endure the blameless but not the blameworthy,' 'I can endure the uncontaminated but not the contaminated,' 'I can endure the supramundane but not the mundane,' 'I can endure purity but not defilement,' 'I can endure nirvana but not samsara,' Shariputra!

If one accords with emptiness, one does not diminish views, and in that empty nature there is also no increase or benefit. Such acceptance is called the ultimate acceptance of a bodhisattva.

if one accords with emptiness, one does not diminish practices, and in the nature of no action there is also no increase or benefit;
if one accords with emptiness, one does not diminish afflictions, and in the nature of exhausting delusions there is also no increase or benefit;
if one accords with emptiness, one does not diminish unwholesomeness, and in that wholesome nature there is also no increase or benefit;

If there is a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who fills immeasurable worlds equal to the sands in the Ganges river with all priceless precious treasures and uses them to make offerings to immeasurable TathÄgatas, Arhats, and Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas,

Having heard such a subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, after hearing this sÅ«tra they go to a secluded place, focus their thoughts, contemplate such dharmas, diligently cultivate and study, and cause those bodhisattvas who have not yet studied to love and practice.

In this way, because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice right effort, they gather immeasurable wonderful roots of goodness, which cannot be compared to those who practice giving.
